subject: Re: [junit] Tests naming
msgSnippet: On  0, J. B. Rainsberger  wrote: Thank you for the feedback! Please see my comments below. ... In my experience, there are several
messageBody:
On 0, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...> wrote:

Thank you for the feedback! Please see my comments below.

> >As far as I learned, usually we shall test behaviour and design,
> >not specific classes and methods. This allows us to keep tests
> >task-oriented and not implementation-oriented.
> >Considering this, I see the following possible decisions regarding
> >tests organization:
> >
> >1. For Functional tests:
> > - all tests for a use case (and, possibly, alternative flows) are
> > placed into a single package with an appropriate name.
>
> Generally there is one test per use case scenario (different flow
> through the use case). Choosing to write more or fewer tests should be
> done thoughtfully.

In my experience, there are several alternative flows for a ordinary
use case. And I see reasonable to test at least two of them: basic
flow and error flow. What do you think?

>
> > - each test scenario is placed into single class with appropriate
> name.
>
> Each use case scenario is a test. Test classes should almost always
> evolve based around a fixture, not some other arbitrary organization
> mechanism. A given use case may be implemented as its own Customer Test
> class, but it is usually better to let the organization of tests into
> TestCase implementations depend on shared fixture requirements.

But we can share fixtures using inheritance as well. I have two points here:

- for a complicated test case it may be better to keep it in a separate class.
- It is easier to get full list of existing functional tests if we put
each test case into a single class. Getting the list is quite usual
task requested by QA department or customer (or I'm wrong here?)


>
> >2. For Unit tests:
> > - test package shall be the same as for the production code,
> > but it is better to use a different source tree.
> > - for simple classes (such as value objects) it is OK to name
> > test classes after the name of the class under test
> > (like UTestFooBar or FooBarTest). Names of test methods,
> > in its turn, may include the name of the tested method.
> > - for complex classes, which require a complex fixture to be set,
> > test case class shall be named using fixture description.
> > (The issue was discussed previously on this list).
> > Test method name in this case shall describe the tested behaviour.
>
> The last point is the general case, and the previous points are special
> cases when the tests (not the code under test) are very simple.

Agreed. The issue here is to fugure out proper fixture class when you
want to add a new test (for instance, when you find a bug). The task
may become more complicated if you never seen the code before and there
are nobody to ask (bad things happen). I see two possible solutions:

- Use IDE features to find usages of tested code (if you have such IDE)
- Make a error in the production code and see which test breaks.

>
> >3. For Integration Tests:
> > - I suggest, names of Integration tests must differ from Unit
> tests.
> > Usually, integration tests run longer, and consequently, more
> seldom.
> > That's why it is convinient to name them differently. One may name
>
> > unit tests using UTest prefix, anf Integration tests using ITest
> >prefix.
>
> On a past project, we used tag interfaces to distinguish Programmer
> Tests from Customer Tests. This made it easy to write a TestRunner that
> picked one or the other or both when building a test suite. You may
> find this technique useful.

I saw an article where static variable with specific value was used
to mark a test and TestSuite class used reflection to include only
tests with specific value of the variable. It is quite close to your
approach.

What for me, I use ant to build/run my test suites. That's why I
suggest class naming approach.

>
> Also, place the different kinds of tests in different packages in order
> to reduce the number of naming collisions.

Sorry, I don't see your point clearly. Are you talking about unit tests,
functional tests?

>
> I have to say that your list of points is excellent and should be
> turned into a short article on the subject.

Thank you very much. Actually, I thought about it and I'll possibly
try to write one.

With best regards,
